title: How to Get Hair Out of Your Shower or Bathtub Drain

steps.title: Boil a pot of water and pour it down the drain.
steps.content: Boil a pot of water and pour it down the drain. This is the easiest way to take care of a hair-clogged shower or bathtub drain. [1] X Research source Fill a tea kettle or pot with water and bring it to a boil. Slowly pour the water down the drain, giving the hot liquid time to move through the hair and melt the grease that’s holding the clog together. [2] X Research source Wait 15 minutes, then run the shower to see if the water runs freely down the drain. If the clog is still there, try one of the other methods below. For larger clogs, you may need to use a large pot or multiple tea kettles full of boiling water.

steps.title: Pour baking soda and vinegar down the drain.
steps.content: Pour baking soda and vinegar down the drain. Carefully pour 1 cup (128 grams) baking soda down the drain, then chase it with 1 cup (240 mL) of distilled white vinegar. The drain should start bubbling and fizzing, dissolving the hair, grease, and dirt clogging the pipes. [3] X Research source Optionally, use a funnel to make sure all the baking soda goes under the drain guard. Mix the baking soda with ½ cup of table salt and heat up the vinegar for extra cleaning power. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Let the drain bubble for 15 minutes, then pour boiling water.
steps.content: Let the drain bubble for 15 minutes, then pour boiling water. Heat a pot or kettle of boiling water, then pour it down the drain to flush the baking soda, vinegar, and dissolved hair from your pipes. [5] X Research source Wait another 15 minutes, then turn on the water. If the water still pools in your tub, try another method.

steps.title: Remove the drain guard and suck the hair out with a wet vacuum hose.
steps.content: Remove the drain guard and suck the hair out with a wet vacuum hose. Professional plumber James Schuelke says to “take the drain cover off the shower, and you literally put the [wet] vacuum hose right up against the drain and turn the vacuum on.” [6] X Expert Source James Schuelke Professional Plumber Expert Interview. 1 October 2019. To remove the drain guard or cover, unscrew it or pry it up using a flathead screwdriver and a pair of pliers. [7] X Research source Schuelke says “That will extract all of the organic matter, hair, soap scum, all of that, that literally will just take everything out of there.” [8] X Expert Source James Schuelke Professional Plumber Expert Interview. 1 October 2019. After you’re done, put the drain guard back on and run the water. If the water doesn’t flow smoothly down the drain, try another method.

steps.title: Take the drain guard off and pull out the hair by hand.
steps.content: Take the drain guard off and pull out the hair by hand. Plumber David Balkan says “balls of hair or other debris” might be at the top of your drain and all you need to do is “put a pair of rubber gloves on and pull it right out.” [9] X Expert Source David Balkan Professional Plumber & CEO of Balkan Sewer & Water Main Expert Interview. 29 April 2021. Twist, screw off, or pry up the drain guard, then reach into the drain and try to pull anything you can see out of it. [10] X Research source Use a flashlight to spot the clog if you can’t see it immediately. Optionally, use pliers or tweezers to remove the hair. You can also use a chopstick, fork, or long screwdriver to grab the hair. Twirl the tool slightly as you pull the hair out of the drain and repeat until the pathway is clear. Replace the drain guard and run the water. If your shower or bathtub drain is still clogged, try a different method.

steps.title: Bend a wire hanger into a straight line, leaving a small hook at one end.
steps.content: Bend a wire hanger into a straight line, leaving a small hook at one end. Use your hands to bend a wire hanger as flat and straight as you can. Make a small curl at one end of the hanger that can fit into the drain. [11] X Research source You may need to wear work gloves to give you enough traction to bend the wire. It doesn’t matter if there are a few slight bends in the hanger. Just try to bend the center part as straight as you can so it can fit down the drain. Optionally, bend the other end of the hanger into a half-square shape you can use as a twisting handle. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the guard, insert the hook into the drain, and pull up the hair.
steps.content: Remove the guard, insert the hook into the drain, and pull up the hair. Unscrew the drain guard, twist it counterclockwise, or pry it up with a flathead screwdriver. If you find a screw underneath, unscrew that too. Push the hook end of the wire into the drain until you feel resistance. Fish the hook under the hair blockage and pull it up. [13] X Research source If you have a shower and tub combination, you might be able to take out the drain guard by pushing it down and twisting it to the left. Carefully move the wire up and down through the blockage to collect as much hair as possible. The hanger shouldn’t get stuck on anything, but if it does, push it back down, wiggle it, and try pulling it out again.

steps.title: Rinse the drain with baking soda, vinegar, and hot water.
steps.content: Rinse the drain with baking soda, vinegar, and hot water. This can help flush out any leftover hair or grime in the drain. Sprinkle 1 cup (128 grams) baking soda into the drain, then pour 1 cup (240 mL) white vinegar. Let it fizz for 15 minutes before flushing the drain with a pot or kettle of boiling water. [14] X Research source Alternatively, just pour a kettle or pot full of boiling water directly down the drain. After you’re done, reattach the drain guard. Turn on the shower—if the water doesn’t flow down the drain, try another unclogging method.

steps.title: Remove the guard and insert the snake or auger into the drain.
steps.content: Remove the guard and insert the snake or auger into the drain. Twist, unscrew, or pry the guard off the drain. Insert the end of a plastic drain snake or metal auger into the drain pipe until it won’t move any further. [15] X Research source When you feel resistance, you’ve hit the clog. If you have a tub and shower combination, try pressing the guard down and twisting it to the left to remove it. Wear safety glasses and rubber gloves while handling an auger or drain snake to protect yourself from debris and standing water that may splash up. [16] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source

steps.title: Rotate the snake or auger counterclockwise until the clog is gone.
steps.content: Rotate the snake or auger counterclockwise until the clog is gone. Rotate the plastic drain snake or crank the metal auger’s handle counterclockwise to break up the clog. Continue to crank and push the auger or snake down until you don’t feel resistance anymore. Slowly pull the snake or auger out of the drain and dispose of the hair. [17] X Research source If your tool gets stuck, wiggle it up, down, and side to side until it comes out easily. Plastic drain snakes are meant to only be used once, while metal augers can be reused.

steps.title: Rinse the drain with hot water and put the guard back on.
steps.content: Rinse the drain with hot water and put the guard back on. Turn the hot water tap on full force and rinse out the drain for about a minute to make sure the drain is clear. [18] X Research source You might see bits of grime and debris come out of the drain. Once the drain is clear, put the drain guard back on. If you see large globs of hair rise to the surface, pull them out with your hands and discard them. If the drain is still clogged, use a second drain snake or try a different method.

steps.title: Take off the drain guard and use a cup plunger to dislodge the hair.
steps.content: Take off the drain guard and use a cup plunger to dislodge the hair. Fill the shower or tub with enough water to cover the lip of the plunger cup. Place the plunger so the cup covers the drain opening and push it up and down for a few minutes. [19] X Research source The force of the pressurized water can push the hair clog through the drain. [20] X Research source If you have a drain with standing water on top of it, Balkan says that a “good old typical plunger works well” to unclog it. [21] X Expert Source David Balkan Professional Plumber & CEO of Balkan Sewer & Water Main Expert Interview. 29 April 2021. Optionally, flush out the drain with a pot or kettle of boiling water. Put the drain guard back on and turn on the water. If the clog is still there, try again or use a different method.

steps.title: Pour a chemical cleaner down the drain as a last resort.
steps.content: Pour a chemical cleaner down the drain as a last resort. Shower drain cleaners are easy to use—all you need to do is open the bottle and pour it down the drain. Most hair and grime clogs will disappear in 10 to 15 minutes. However, chemical cleaners can be environmentally harmful and can weaken PVC and old metal pipes. [22] X Research source Enzymatic drain cleaners are a gentle and eco-friendly alternative, but they may have to sit in the drain longer than 15 minutes. [23] X Research source Look for one that targets hair clogs. [24] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source Check the label to see how much of the bottle to pour into the drain and if you need to wear protective clothing, like safety glasses or rubber gloves. Optionally, flush the drain with warm or hot water for 1 minute to clear away the chemicals and any leftover debris. If the clog is still there, it may be time to contact a professional.

steps.title: Contact a plumber if none of the methods above unclog the drain.
steps.content: Contact a plumber if none of the methods above unclog the drain. If none of the above at-home methods work, you may have roots or other small objects stuck in your pipes that need to be removed by a professional. [25] X Research source Balkan says that “a professional drain cleaner has an air pressure gun and when you pump it up, it will blow the clog out.” [26] X Expert Source David Balkan Professional Plumber & CEO of Balkan Sewer & Water Main Expert Interview. 29 April 2021. If you see rust debris coming out from your pipes, that’s another sign to call a professional. Let the plumber know what cleaners and methods you used to avoid any damage to your pipes.

steps.title: Buy a shower drain hair catcher to stop the issue at the source.
steps.content: Buy a shower drain hair catcher to stop the issue at the source. A shower hair catcher can be an efficient way to prevent clumps of hair from collecting and eventually causing a clog in your drain. [27] X Research source To clean it daily, just pull it out of the drain and scoop the hair into the trash.

steps.title: Brush your hair before or after you shower to keep hair out of the drain.
steps.content: Brush your hair before or after you shower to keep hair out of the drain. This way, the majority of your loose hair follicles end up in the trash instead of collecting in your shower drain. [28] X Research source If you need to brush your hair in the shower, designate a place to collect the hair instead of letting it collect in the tub or on top of the drain.

steps.title: Flush the drain every month with baking soda and vinegar.
steps.content: Flush the drain every month with baking soda and vinegar. To prevent hair and grime buildup, pour 1 cup (128 grams) baking soda and 1 cup (240 mL) of white distilled vinegar down the drain. Wait 10 minutes, then flush out the pipes with a pot or kettle full of boiling water. [29] X Research source If you think hard water is building up in your pipes and causing clogs, you may have to ask a plumber to install a water softening system in your home. [30] X Research source In addition, take off the guard and remove the hair and grime at the top of the drain every month. [31] X Research source
